prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
The title of "Xiangqi King" was taken away from Yan Chenglong following accusations of unacceptable conduct. He is also suspected of cheating by utilizing a device akin to anal beads with wireless transmission capabilities.

Yan, aged 48, has been expelled from the Xiangqi community and prohibited from participating in competitions for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) admits that they cannot definitively confirm the cheating allegations.

Xiangqi, a centuries-old game, has garnered widespread popularity in Asia.

The CXA revealed that Yan celebrated his victory at a national tournament on Hainan Island by consuming alcohol with companions in his hotel room. Subsequently, he allegedly caused damage to the hotel's bath and breached public order and moral standards by defecating there.

Rumors swirled online accusing Yan of cheating using anal beads equipped for signal transmission. The CXA acknowledged that, at this time, there is insufficient evidence to substantiate such claims.

As a result of his unsavory behavior, Yan relinquished his title and was restricted from competing for a year.

The CXA did not disclose the exact prize money forfeited by Yan, but Xiangqi tournaments frequently offer winners substantial amounts, reaching tens of thousands of yuan, according to AFP.

Yan Chenglong, 48 years old, had his "Xiangqi King" title revoked due to alleged misconduct. He is under suspicion of cheating with the help of a suspected device similar to anal beads, capable of wireless transmission.

The Xiangqi community and the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) have expelled Yan and barred him from participating in competitions for a year.

Despite acknowledging Yan's defeat at a national tournament on Hainan Island, consuming alcohol in his hotel room, and causing damage to the hotel's bath, the CXA cannot definitively prove the cheating accusations.

Rumors of Yan's alleged cheating using signaling devices during games have circulated online. The CXA has stated that there is currently insufficient evidence to support these claims.
